normalised: I remember the day my grandfather, Dada ji, first told me about insurance. I must have been around ten, hovering around him as he meticulously sorted through his documents. He pulled out this faded, thick paper, a life insurance policy he'd taken out ages ago. It looked ancient, honestly, like something out of a history book. "Beta," he said, adjusting his glasses, "this is my peace of mind."

normalised: At the time, it didn't make much sense to me. Peace of mind from a piece of paper? But as I grew older, especially after starting my own family, I began to understand. The thought of leaving my wife, Priya, and my son, Rohan, financially vulnerable, well, it kept me up at night. That's when I seriously started looking at different insurance options.

normalised: The first thing I realized was how overwhelming it all was. Term insurance, endowment policies, U-L-I-Ps, it felt like learning a whole new language. I started with online research, spending hours comparing different policies on Policybazaar and Paisabazaar. The sheer number of options was staggering. I saw term life insurance plans offering coverage up to rupee one crore for a premium of around rupee ten thousand per year. Seemed like a decent deal, but I wanted to be sure.

normalised: I spoke to my colleague, Rakesh, who had recently bought a comprehensive health insurance plan. He recommended I check out I-C-I-C-I Prudential's iProtect Smart plan, mentioning its good claim settlement ratio. He also suggested getting a critical illness rider, covering diseases like cancer, heart attack, etcetera. "Trust me," he said, "Medical expenses can wipe out your savings in no time." His words resonated deeply, especially after hearing about my aunt's battle with cancer a year prior, where the family spent upwards of rupee twenty lakh for treatment.

normalised: Ultimately, I decided to go with a term insurance plan with a sum assured of rupee seventy five lakh and a critical illness rider. I also opted for a health insurance policy for my family, covering hospitalisation expenses up to rupee five lakh per year. The combined premium came to around rupee twenty five thousand annually. A significant amount, no doubt, but worth it for the peace of mind.

normalised: The application process was fairly straightforward, mostly online. I had to upload documents like my Aadhaar card, P-A-N card, and income proof. The medical check-up was a bit of a hassle, but nothing too major. A few blood tests and a general physical examination. The entire process, from application to policy issuance, took about two weeks.

normalised: One thing I learned during this whole process is the importance of reading the fine print. Understanding the exclusions, the waiting periods, and the claim settlement process is crucial. Don't just blindly trust the agent or the marketing material. Do your own research and ask questions. For example, some policies have a thirty day waiting period for certain illnesses.
